pdgm.pdgmnote: Appleyard2007b p. 495f. A:subordinate tenses (and base for A2,B,C);A2:main neg imperf/perf;B:main aff imperf/perf;C:main aff fut
Appleyard2007b p. 495f. A:subordinate tenses (and base for A2,B,C);A2:main neg imperf/perf;B:main aff imperf/perf;C:main aff fut
Appleyard2007b pp. 497-499. Third conjugation verbs:a handful of monosyllabic roots (cf. LEXEMES section).

Appleyard2007b pp. 502f. “A peculiar feature of the verb ‘to be’ in Bilin,shared with the other Agaw languages,is the reversal of aspect,whereby a perfective aspect (past tense) form is used in imprefective (present time) function,and vice versa,as for instance:ni gərwa kəxin sänäkw ‘he was a clever man’. “(p. 501) See LEXEMES section.
Appleyard2007b p. 491. The oblique case is also used for the possessive prefix. The object suffix pronouns,attached to verb,are borrowed from Tigre. NOte sg 2 f form (unique in Agaw).
Appleyard2007b p. 495f. A:subordinate tenses (and base for A2,B,C);A2:main neg imperf/perf;B:main aff imperf/perf;C:main aff fut
Appleyard2007b p. 495f. A:subordinate tenses (and base for A2,B,C);A2:main neg imperf/perf;B:main aff imperf/perf;C:main aff fut

Appleyard2007b pp. 501f. typically denoting continuous actions or ongoing states,comprising usually an adverbial subordinate tense form of the lexical verb followed by an appropriate tense of an auxiliary”(p. 501) – usually ‘be’ or some other stative verb. See LEXEMES section.

Appleyard2007b p. 496. “The two aspects are essentially anifested by different vocalizations of the variable vowel parts of the person marker system (2pl. –dVn-,and 3pl. –Vn-) and the subordinate negativizer (-Vg-)
Appleyard2007b pp. 497-499. Third conjugation verbs:a handful of monosyllabic roots (cf. LEXEMES section).
